body: What about Desired State Configuration?  You have a roadmap article without a single word about DSC...

@JasonFossen DSC team posted a [blog](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2017/09/12/dsc-future-direction-update/) several months back on future direction.  Nothing to report on their roadmap right now, but it's being worked on.

Michael Greene at the AMA two weeks ago said he would be publishing a new article on DSC soon.  When is this new article coming out please?  Can you or Michael give even general or broad indications about the future of DSC?  Thanks

https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/PowerShell-AMA/DSC-on-PowerShell-Core-6-0/td-p/143758
@mgreenegit @Indhukrishna any eta on an update on DSC?

Newer areas of development for PowerShell in the future? 

How about pushing the envelop on the Out-Gridview cmdlet a bit more?

[1a] Allowing the cmdlet to be fed prompts 
and 
[1b] Get feedback responses from a box so a PowerShell developer doesn't have to write a WPF form

- (more so than just getting back a passthru of records for: many, one or no -passthru arguments).
Is powershell 6.0 core is supporting Kerberos-based authentication?
Any update on when responsible product teams are going to provide server side modules (e.g. ActiveDirectory) that will be compatible with PS6?

+1 on @DaveCarnahan 

Yes! There's no mention or intention about the suitable replacement to the GUI on Out-GridView.
I like the Python Tk/TCL but I know you guys are trying some other ones.

:)
For those interested in what I have planned for the Web Cmdlets in 6.1: https://get-powershellblog.blogspot.com/2018/01/powershell-core-61-web-cmdlets-roadmap.html
Is the addition of the '[DSL feature](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3243)' still relevant?
@LaurentDardenne the DSL feature is still something I'd like to enable, but it's not a priority for 6.1
DSC update is out: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2018/01/26/dsc-planning-update-january-2018/
Can we ask for C# ternary and null coalescing operators implementation in 6.1?
@kborowinski if you have not already, please vote and comment on #3239
@markekraus done!

Hi, 
The roadmap sounds promesing, and there seems a lot of work for you guys to achiev.

I had small question:
What about the language / syntax support? 
The article states a lot of new features, but nothing was mentionned about classes:

I have the following few things that keep bugging me when I write classes and would love to seem them appear in a next version:

-Interface creation
-Abastract classes
-Creation of static and non static internal classes
-Implementing comment based help in Classes

These would be really helpfull for the most common scenarios of design patterns.

@Stephanevg can't commit to anything for 6.1 right now for classes improvements.  I have an intern returning as a full time employee on my team starting today.  His intern project was language related, so I'm hoping he can pick up some of the classes improvement work otherwise it'll be part of 6.2 plan.
I have get/set adding commit over year frozen :-)
I have created a separate issue here https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6418 which could allow the tracking of this easier.

The roadmap says 

> This means that weâ€™re targeting a late June,  early July 2018 release for PSCore 6.1.

It's now August... when can we expect the release of PSCore 6.1?
@Dargmuesli We expect RC in days.
@iSazonov nice, what's your estimation of the final (non-RC) release date?
Usually ~2 weeks after RC.
No new roadmap? No new milestones?
@iSazonov This is specific for 6.1, will have something regarding 6.2 "soon"
